text: Summary of Major Points: Christopher B. Field, PhD1, Carnegie Institution for Science2
label: HH1

text: Energy and Commerce Committee, Subcommittee on Energy and Power:  “Climate
label: HH3

text: Science and the EPA’s Greenhouse Gas Regulations”, March 8, 2011
label: HH3

text: The modern understanding of climate change is based on many lines of robust,
label: BODY

text: independent evidence, providing a foundation of well established conclusions, including the
label: BODY

text: following, from the US Global Change Research Program: (1) Global warming is unequivocal
label: BODY

text: and primarily human-induced, (2) Climate changes are underway in the United States and are
label: BODY

text: projected to grow, and (3) Widespread climate-related impacts are occurring now and are
label: BODY

text: expected to increase.
label: BODY

text: Against these foundations, I want to talk about the observed (not simulated) climate
label: BODY

text: sensitivity of two important processes – US agriculture and wildfires in the Western US.
label: BODY

text: • Observed yields of corn, soybean, and cotton all have clear temperature thresholds, below
label: BODY

text: which yields are stable and above which yields fall quickly with rising temperatures. A
label: BODY

text: single day of 104˚F instead of 84˚F reduces corn yields by about 7%.  Modest warming
label: BODY

text: over the century is expected to reduce yields by 30-46% below levels that would
label: BODY

text: otherwise occur, and severe warming could reduce yields by 63-82%
label: BODY

text: • Large wildfires in the Western US are more frequent, last longer, and occur over a longer
label: BODY

text: fire season in years that are unusually warm.  Based on observed patterns, a 1.8˚F
label: BODY

text: warming would increase the annual area burned from 1.3 million acres (the average for
label: BODY

text: 1970-2003) to 4.5 million acres.
label: BODY

text: 1 Any opinions, findings, conclusions, or recommendations expressed in this publication are those of the author and
label: BODY

text: do not necessarily reflect those of the Carnegie Institution for Science or the IPCC
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: humanity.
label: BODY

text: Statement of
label: HH2

text: Christopher B. Field, PhD3
label: BODY

text: Director, Department of Global Ecology
label: HH2

label: BODY

text: Co-chair, Working Group II of the IPCC

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Climate Science and the EPA’s Greenhouse Gas Regulations
label: HH3

text: Introduction
label: HH3

text: I thank Chairman Upton, Ranking Member Waxman, Chairman of the Subcommittee
label: BODY

text: Whitfield, Ranking Member of the Subcommittee Rush, and the other Members of the
label: BODY

text: Committee for the opportunity to speak with you today on observed impacts of climate on
label: BODY

text: important processes in our country.  My name is Christopher Field.  I am director of the
label: BODY

text: Department of Global Ecology at the Carnegie Institution for Science, a not-for-profit
label: BODY

text: organization dedicated to basic research for the benefit of humanity.  In addition, I am a
label: BODY

text: professor in the Department of Environmental Earth System Science and the Department of
label: BODY

text: Biology at Stanford University.  Since September of 2008, I have served as co-chair of Working
label: BODY

text: Group 2 of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.  Working Group 2 is tasked with
label: BODY

text: assessing scientific information concerning impacts of climate change, options for adaptation to
label: BODY

text: climate changes that cannot be avoided, and vulnerability to climate change.
label: BODY

text: My personal research focuses on interactions among climate, the carbon cycle, and
label: BODY

text: ecosystem processes, using approaches that range from ecosystem-scale climate manipulations to
label: BODY

text: global climate models.  I have published over 200 peer-reviewed papers in leading scientific
label: BODY

text: journals, and was a coordinating lead author on the topic “North America” for the Working
label: BODY

text: Group 2 contribution to the IPCC Fourth Assessment Report.  I have served on many committees
label: BODY

text: of the National Research Council and International Scientific Organizations.  I am an elected
label: BODY

text: member of the US National Academy of Sciences and the American Academy of Arts and
label: BODY

text: Sciences as well as an elected Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of
label: BODY

text: Science.
label: BODY

text: In today’s testimony, I will focus on two aspects of observed sensitivity of important
label: BODY

text: processes to climate.  The two processes are agricultural yields in the United States and wildfire
label: BODY

text: in the Western United States.  The sensitivities I want to discuss today are based on observations
label: BODY

text: and not on simulations.  All of the material I will be discussing today is based on publications in
label: BODY

text: peer-reviewed scientific journals or on national or international assessments of thousands of
label: BODY

text: scientific sources.
label: BODY

text: Robust Foundations of Current Knowledge
label: HH3

text: The starting point for the material I want to discuss today is a series of robust conclusions
label: BODY

text: from climate science, synthesized in a number of recent major assessments including two 2010
label: BODY

text: reports from the US National Academy of Sciences, “Climate Stabilization Targets: Emissions,
label: BODY

text: Concentrations, and Impacts over Decades to Millennia” (Solomon 2010), and “Advancing the
label: BODY

text: Science of Climate Change” (Matson 2010), the 2009 report from the US Global Change
label: BODY

text: Research Program, “Global Climate Change Impacts in the United States” (Karl et al. 2009) and
label: BODY

text: the Fourth Assessment Report of the IPCC (IPCC 2007a, c, b).  These documents provide a
label: BODY

text: scientifically rich picture of a changing climate, the mechanisms that underlie observed and
label: BODY

text: projected changes, impacts of climate change on individuals, ecosystems, economies, and
label: BODY

text: regions, and the costs and benefits of changing practices to decrease the amount of climate
label: BODY

text: change from a business-as-usual scenario.
label: BODY

text: The following 10 points, quoted from (Karl et al. 2009), form the foundation for any
label: BODY

text: discussion of climate change and its impacts:
label: BODY

text: “1. Global warming is unequivocal and primarily human-induced.
label: BODY

text: Global temperature has increased over the past 50 years. This observed increase is due primarily
label: BODY

text: to human induced emissions of heat-trapping gases.
label: BODY

text: 2. Climate changes are underway in the United States and are projected to grow.
label: BODY

text: Climate-related changes are already observed in the United States and its coastal waters. These
label: BODY

text: include increases in heavy downpours, rising temperature and sea level, rapidly retreating
label: BODY

text: glaciers, thawing permafrost, lengthening growing seasons, lengthening ice-free seasons in the
label: BODY

text: ocean and on lakes and rivers, earlier snowmelt, and alterations in river flows. These changes are
label: BODY

text: projected to grow.
label: BODY

text: 3. Widespread climate-related impacts are occurring now and are expected to increase.
label: BODY

text: Climate changes are already affecting water, energy, transportation, agriculture, ecosystems, and
label: BODY

text: health. These impacts are different from region to region and will grow under projected climate
label: BODY

text: change.
label: BODY

text: 4. Climate change will stress water resources.
label: BODY

text: Water is an issue in every region, but the nature of the potential impacts varies. Drought, related
label: BODY

text: to reduced precipitation, increased evaporation, and increased water loss from plants, is an
label: BODY

text: important issue in many regions, especially in the West. Floods and water quality problems are
label: BODY

text: likely to be amplified by climate change in most regions. Declines in mountain snowpack are
label: BODY

text: important in the West and Alaska where snowpack provides vital natural water storage.
label: BODY

text: 5. Crop and livestock production will be increasingly challenged.
label: BODY

text: Many crops show positive responses to elevated carbon dioxide and low levels of warming, but
label: BODY

text: higher levels of warming often negatively affect growth and yields. Increased pests, water stress,
label: BODY

text: diseases, and weather extremes will pose adaptation challenges for crop and livestock
label: BODY

text: production.
label: BODY

text: 6. Coastal areas are at increasing risk from sea-level rise and storm surge.
label: BODY

text: Sea-level rise and storm surge place many U.S. coastal areas at increasing risk of erosion and
label: BODY

text: flooding, especially along the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, Pacific Islands, and parts of Alaska.
label: BODY

text: Energy and transportation infrastructure and other property in coastal areas are very likely to be
label: BODY

text: adversely affected.
label: BODY

text: 7. Risks to human health will increase.
label: BODY

text: Harmful health impacts of climate change are related to increasing heat stress, waterborne
label: BODY

text: diseases, poor air quality, extreme weather events, and diseases transmitted by insects and
label: BODY

text: rodents. Reduced cold stress provides some benefits. Robust public health infrastructure can
label: BODY

text: reduce the potential for negative impacts.
label: BODY

text: 8. Climate change will interact with many social and environmental stresses.
label: BODY

text: Climate change will combine with pollution, population growth, overuse of resources,
label: BODY

text: urbanization, and other social, economic, and environmental stresses to create larger impacts
label: BODY

text: than from any of these factors alone.
label: BODY

text: 9. Thresholds will be crossed, leading to large changes in climate and ecosystems.
label: BODY

text: There are a variety of thresholds in the climate system and ecosystems. These thresholds
label: BODY

text: determine, for example, the presence of sea ice and permafrost, and the survival of species, from
label: BODY

text: fish to insect pests, with implications for society. With further climate change, the crossing of
label: BODY

text: additional thresholds is expected.
label: BODY

text: 10. Future climate change and its impacts depend on choices made today.
label: BODY

text: The amount and rate of future climate change depend primarily on current and future human-
label: BODY

text: caused emissions of heat-trapping gases and airborne particles. Responses involve reducing
label: BODY

text: emissions to limit future warming, and adapting to the changes that are unavoidable.”
label: BODY

text: Recent Results: Observed Responses of the Temperature Sensitivity of US Agriculture
label: HH3

text: Globally and in the US, advancements in agriculture are among the crowning
label: BODY

text: accomplishments of human ingenuity.  Especially over the last century, yields have increased
label: BODY

text: dramatically (Lobell et al. 2009), more than keeping pace with the growth of human population.
label: BODY

text: One recent analysis concludes that agricultural intensification since 1961 has increased yields so
label: BODY

text: much that the area in crops has not needed to change, even as demand has soared (Burney et al.
label: BODY

text: 2010).  As a consequence, intensification of agriculture has prevented deforestation that
label: BODY

text: otherwise would have emitted 161 billion tons of carbon to the atmosphere.
label: BODY

text: Over recent decades, yields of most major crops have increased at 1-2% per year (Lobell
label: BODY

text: and Field 2007), but an increasing body of evidence indicates that obtaining these yield increases
label: BODY

text: is becoming more and more difficult, as climate change acts to resist or reverse yield increases
label: BODY

text: from improvements in management and breeding. Using global records of yield trends in the
label: BODY

text: world’s six major food crops since 1961, my colleague David Lobell and I (Lobell and Field
label: BODY

text: 2007) concluded that, at the global scale, effects of warming are already visible, with global
label: BODY

text: yields of wheat, corn, and barley reduced since 1981 by 40 million tons per year below the levels
label: BODY

text: that would occur without the warming.  As of 2002 (the last year analyzed in the study), this
label: BODY

text: represents an economic loss of approximately $5 billion per year.
label: BODY

text: In the United States, the observed temperature sensitivity of three major crops is even
label: BODY

text: more striking.  Based on a careful county-by county analysis of patterns of climate and yields of
label: BODY

text: corn, soybeans, and cotton, Schlenker and Roberts (Schlenker and Roberts 2009) concluded that
label: BODY

text: observed yields from all farms and farmers are relatively insensitive to temperature up to a
label: BODY

text: threshold but fall rapidly as temperatures rise above the threshold.  For farms in the United
label: BODY

text: States, the temperature threshold is 84˚F for corn, 86˚F for soybeans, and 90˚F for cotton.  For
label: BODY

text: corn, a single day at 104˚F instead of 84˚F reduces observed yields by about 7%.  These
label: BODY

text: temperature sensitivities are based on observed responses, including data from all of the US
label: BODY

text: counties that grow cotton and all of the Eastern counties that grow corn or soybeans.  These are
label: BODY

text: not simulated responses.  They are observed in the aggregate yields of thousands of farms in
label: BODY

text: thousands of locations.
label: BODY

text: The temperature sensitivity observed by Schlenker and Roberts (Schlenker and Roberts
label: BODY

text: 2009) suggests a challenging future for US agriculture.  Unless we can develop varieties with
label: BODY

text: improved heat tolerance, modest warming (based on the IPCC B1 scenario) by the end of the 21st
label: BODY

text: century will reduce yields by 30-46%.  With a high estimate of climate change (based on the
label: BODY

text: IPCC A1FI scenario), the loss of yield is 63-82%.  These three major crops, in some ways the
label: BODY

text: core of US agriculture, are exquisitely sensitive to warming.  This result is very clear.  We may
label: BODY

text: be able to breed warming tolerant varieties, and it is possible that some of the yield losses due to
label: BODY

text: warming will be compensated by positive responses to elevated atmospheric CO2 (Long et al.
label: BODY

text: 2006), but we will be trying to improve yields in a setting where warming is like an anchor
label: BODY

text: pulling us back.
label: BODY

text: Recent Results: Observed Responses of the Temperature Sensitivity of Wildfires in the
label: HH3

text: Western US
label: HH3

text: Wildfire is a common threat in the Western US.  While historical, low-intensity wildfires
label: BODY

text: can play an important role in sustaining the health of ecosystems (Minnich 1983), large, high-
label: BODY

text: intensity wildfires destroy lives and homes, impact air quality, degrade watersheds, reduce
label: BODY

text: economic activity, and eliminate wildlife habitat.  In recent years, suppression costs have been
label: BODY

text: over $1 billion per annum (Littell et al. 2009).
label: BODY

text: Westerling and colleagues (Westerling et al. 2006) compiled a database of 1166 large
label: BODY

text: wildfires in the US during the period from 1970 to 2003.  They observed a large increase in fire
label: BODY

text: frequency, duration, and in the length of the fire season after the mid 1980s.  This increase in fire
label: BODY

text: activity was strongly related to warm spring and summer temperatures.  Over this period, the
label: BODY

text: length of time from snow-melt in the spring to the first snow-fall in the autumn is a good
label: BODY

text: predictor of the fire risk.
label: BODY

text: Littell and colleagues (Littell et al. 2009) looked at a longer series of fire records and
label: BODY

text: analyzed the data for relationships with temperature and rainfall.  They found that, for most
label: BODY

text: Western ecosystems, climate is a strong predictor of wildfire area burned, with current-year
label: BODY

text: temperature explaining a significant amount of the variability in most regions.  The striking
label: BODY

text: feature of these results, based on observations and not simulations is the sensitivity.  For most of
label: BODY

text: the West, the annual area burned increases by 200 to over 600% for every 1.8˚F of warming
label: BODY

text: (Solomon 2010).  It is only in the driest regions, where warming makes it too dry for fire, that
label: BODY

text: there is not a strong positive response.  Based on these observed sensitivities, warming of 1.8˚F
label: BODY

text: is expected to increase the area burned from 1.3 million acres per year (the 1970-2003 average)
label: BODY

text: to 4.5 million acres (Solomon 2010).
label: BODY

text: Conclusion
label: HH3

text: Many lines of robust, independent evidence support the conclusion that the climate has
label: BODY

text: been warming over the past century and that human emissions of heat-trapping gases are very
label: BODY

text: likely responsible for much of the warming since the middle of the last century (IPCC 2007d).
label: BODY

text: We are already seeing a wide range of impacts of these climate changes (IPCC 2007e).
label: BODY

text: Although there is scientific uncertainty about the amount of future warming, it is very clear that,
label: BODY

text: unless emissions of heat-trapping gases decrease dramatically, the planet will warm substantially
label: BODY

text: in coming decades.  New data on sensitivities, here I have discussed US agriculture and wildfire,
label: BODY

text: emphasize the magnitude of the risk for the United States.  Based on observations, not
label: BODY

text: simulations, the sensitivities to warming of both agriculture and wildfire are more than sufficient
label: BODY

text: to cause pervasive regional harm, with even modest warming.
label: BODY
